title: Mitigation Strategies for Odour and Corrosion in Sewer Systems
section: Motivation: Save our Sewers from H2S
text:
Motivation: Save our Sewers from H2S

Sewer systems are a critical infrastructure asset

Corrosion of concrete structures
Odour nuisance
Health of utility workers

An increase in the severity of odour and corrosion problems worldwide
Costly to repair corroded sewers and implement dosing stations ðŸ’¶ ðŸ’¶ ðŸ’¶
Necessity to prevent odour nuisance and safeguard workers from H2S







Note


Cost-effective, climate-friendly strategies for H2S control

title: Mitigation Strategies for Odour and Corrosion in Sewer Systems
text:
Research Overview


To investigate the intermittent application of a biological agent that deactivates(SRB) in sewer biofilms
To optomise nitrate dosing based on the dosing point location
To evaluate online liquid- and gas-phase H2S sensors for improving the monitoring of mitigation strategies

title: Mitigation Strategies for Odour and Corrosion in Sewer Systems
text:
Background: Free Nitrous Acid



FNA â†’ produced from nitrite at acidic conditions (a weak monobasic acid)
Only reported studies in Austrialia and USA

Strong biocidal effects â†’ complete suppression sulphide and methane production
Dosed in intervals e.g every 10 days
Cheap alternative â†’ 0.028â‚¬/m3 - 0.34â‚¬/m3




Antimicrobial mechanisms of FNA treatment for sulphide control

Inhibition of bacterial growth
Shut down of protein synthesis
Oxidative stress 



More info: FNA Publication

title: Mitigation Strategies for Odour and Corrosion in Sewer Systems
section: An Example of FNA Dosing Event
text:
An Example of FNA Dosing Event




 

Dissolved sulphide <0.3 mg Lâˆ’1
In some cases H2S in the gas phase > 5 ppm
Occurrence of heterotrophic denitrification

increase pH
reduction in nitrite concentration
higher COD removal rates

sharp nitrite reduction and pH increase â†’ lower FNA concentration




This figure illustrates the H2S liquid and gas phase profiles of an FNA dosing trial. The red lines mark the start and stop of the FNA treatment. - For some trials, it was found that h2s gas concentration exceeded 5 ppm even when the dissolved sulphide concentration was <0,3 mg/L. this is due to pH lowering during the dosing event, which enhances the mass transfer from the bulk wastewater to the sewer atmosphere â†’ which can still contribute to H2S release during the treatment period - Occurrence of heterotrophic denitrification (evidence based on reduction nitrite concentration, increase in ph (0,3 to 1,3) pH units and higher removal rates of COD immediately after a dosing event - Sharp nitrite decrease and pH increase explain the slight inhibitory effects that were observed

title: Mitigation Strategies for Odour and Corrosion in Sewer Systems
section: Biocidal Effects: Recovery Plots (Gompertz Growth Model)
text:
Biocidal Effects: Recovery Plots (Gompertz Growth Model)


\[\begin{equation}
Y=Y_{0}+\left(A-Y_{0}\right)\left(e^{-e^{-\alpha\left(t-t_{0}\right)}}\right)
\end{equation}\]


Y â€“ H2S ratio (-)  Y0 â€“ residual H2S ratio (-) Aâ€“amplitude (-)  \(\alpha\)â€“ recovery rate (dâˆ’1) t0â€“time of maximum recovery rate (d) 



Little to no biocidal effects for concentrations 0.08 to 0.56 mg N Lâˆ’1)
Dosing under active mixing states are likely to improve that mass FNA into the sewer biofilm matrix
FNA concentration and exposure had the most influence on the recovery of SRB activity

title: Mitigation Strategies for Odour and Corrosion in Sewer Systems
text: Biocidal Effects: Comparing the RT50

title: Mitigation Strategies for Odour and Corrosion in Sewer Systems
section: Conclusion: FNA as an Alternative Countermeasure
text:
Conclusion: FNA as an Alternative Countermeasure

Concentrations as high as 13.3 mg N Lâˆ’1 were insufficient to achieve long-lasting inactivation of SRB activity
Longer exposure times and higher FNA concentrations have a stronger biocidal effect
The high nitrite consumption rates and pH increase all provide evidence of the survival of SRB in the presence of nitrite â†’ an indication that the sewer biofilms are resistant to FNA

Important to factor in the contribution N2O formation and release
Pilot plant operation symptomatic of a system with severe sediment accumulation

a key factor affecting SRB suppression

title: Mitigation Strategies for Odour and Corrosion in Sewer Systems
section: Future Research: Outlook to FNA Investigations
text:
Future Research: Outlook to FNA Investigations

Future understanding of the dominating processes during FNA treatment

Microbiome composition â€“ sequencing of bacterial DNA of biofilms obtained from the pressure sewer

To what extent does FNA contribute to N2O formation and release
Longer expoures times
Combining mechanical flushing followed by FNA treatment
